documentType: prison administrative records and email correspondence
summary: This document contains a series of administrative logs and email correspondence related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It includes suicide watch observation logs from July 23-24, 2019, and emails from August 2019 regarding the release of his medical and mental health records to his defense attorneys following his death. This document contains email correspondence from August 2019 regarding the scheduling of a court hearing after Jeffrey Epstein's death and internal BOP communications about the timeline of events leading to his death. It includes an order from Judge Berman and discussions about prison procedures. This document contains a court order scheduling a hearing regarding the dismissal of charges against Jeffrey Epstein following his death, and a series of internal Bureau of Prisons emails. The emails include a solicitation letter to Epstein from a mathematician, and correspondence from Epstein's attorney regarding his conditions of confinement. This document contains email correspondence and administrative logs related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in July 2019. It includes attorney communications about Epstein's conditions of confinement and a Suicide Watch Chronological Log covering the period around his placement on suicide watch. This document contains email correspondence related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York in July-August 2019. It includes communications between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff, Epstein's attorney, and a federal judge regarding logistics, a judicial inquiry, and the drafting of a reconstruction report following Epstein's death. This is a Bureau of Prisons psychological reconstruction report analyzing the death by suicide of inmate Jeffrey Epstein on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Complex in New York. The report details Epstein's background, legal history, institutional behavior, mental health assessments, and the circumstances leading to his death, while also identifying numerous procedural failures and inconsistencies in his supervision. This document is a collection of internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) emails from July to December 2019 concerning the incarceration and death of Jeffrey Epstein. It includes communications about his removal from suicide watch, media inquiries, policy changes, staff hiring, and efforts to reconstruct his inmate records after his death. This document contains Bureau of Prisons Special Housing Unit (SHU) records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein (Reg. No. 76318-054) from July 7 to August 3, 2019, at the New York MCC. It includes daily logs of his confinement, staff signatures, and medical checks, showing he was placed in the SHU pending classification. The document also includes email correspondence from August 12, 2019, where BOP staff discuss reconstructing the 292 data for Epstein and provide a chronological log noting he was transferred to psych observation on July 24, 2019. This document contains Bureau of Prisons suicide watch observation logs for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 23-24, 2019, and email correspondence from August 2019 regarding the reconstruction of his administrative records (SRO/292 forms) following his death. The emails show BOP officials urgently requesting data on Epstein's Special Housing Unit (SHU) reviews. This document contains Bureau of Prisons administrative forms reviewing Jeffrey Epstein's placement in special housing (solitary confinement) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York in July-August 2019, along with internal BOP emails discussing his conditions, complaints, and the disposition of his inmate trust account funds after his death. It reveals concerns about his treatment, self-harm, and administrative procedures following his death. This document is a collection of email correspondence from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) regarding media inquiries and internal logs about conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York following Jeffrey Epstein's death. It includes a forwarded media inquiry about staff morale and policy changes post-Epstein, and an attached chronological log detailing Epstein's transfer to psych observation. This document contains Bureau of Prisons (BOP) records related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death, including suicide watch logs from July 2019, internal emails discussing media coverage of his death and prison conditions, and an email regarding a judicial inquiry. It reveals administrative details of his suicide watch and internal BOP communication following his death. This document contains a series of email exchanges between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York and court personnel regarding the incarceration and death of Jeffrey Epstein. It includes communications about his suicide watch status, court hearings, and internal discussions about media coverage of his autopsy. This document contains email correspondence between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff regarding inmate Jeffrey Epstein's medical/mental health records, mortality review, and cell conditions after his death. It includes internal communications about obtaining autopsy reports and reactions to media coverage of his autopsy. This document contains Bureau of Prisons administrative records related to Jeffrey Epstein's suicide watch and psychological observation at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York in July 2019, along with email correspondence between BOP staff and a federal prosecutor regarding the investigation into his injuries. It includes suicide watch logs, inmate history records, and emails discussing an incident report for self-mutilation and an investigation into his cellmate. This document contains email correspondence between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) officials regarding media inquiries and internal communications about Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration, suicide watch, and death at MCC New York. It includes discussions about public statements, timelines of events, and post-incident facility conditions and staffing. This document is a collection of email correspondence from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) system, primarily from December 2019 and August 2019. It includes internal BOP emails regarding media inquiries about conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) after Jeffrey Epstein's death, a forwarded reporter inquiry about a potential leak regarding Epstein's death, a Google Alert summary of news about the BOP post-Epstein, and an official notification of Epstein's death to the US Marshals Service. The emails reveal BOP's internal communications and media response efforts following the high-profile incident. This document contains email correspondence from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) regarding the death of Jeffrey Epstein by apparent suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York on August 10, 2019, and subsequent media inquiries about conditions at MCC following his death. It includes the official death notification to the court and internal discussions about responding to a reporter's questions. This document contains a series of email exchanges from 2019-2020 among Bureau of Prisons (BOP) and DOJ staff regarding media inquiries, staffing questions, and internal communications about Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration, medical status, and death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It reveals internal coordination on public statements, congressional interest, and post-mortem information leaks. This document contains email correspondence from the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) regarding media inquiries and internal discussions about conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York following Jeffrey Epstein's death. It includes a draft Q&A for the NY Daily News, a Google Alert email about Epstein's suicide, and internal emails discussing the investigation into his injuries and the charges against correctional officers. This document contains email correspondence from July-August 2019 between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff and federal prosecutors regarding the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's injuries while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). It also includes an application for a paralegal, Samanta Honigman, to work on Epstein's case. This document is a collection of email correspondence and forms from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) system, primarily concerning administrative matters related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and the aftermath of his death. It includes a legal representative application, media inquiries about prison conditions, a Google Alert summary, and a request to add an attorney to Epstein's visitor list. This document is a collection of email correspondence and news clippings from August 2019, primarily concerning the aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody. It includes an attorney directory entry for Erika Kellerhals, a forwarded email of news clips about Epstein's death and prison conditions, a Google Alert email sent to a BOP official about federal prisoners, and an internal BOP draft Q&A regarding media inquiries about conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) post-Epstein. This document contains email correspondence between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff and legal personnel regarding the conditions of confinement and media inquiries related to Jeffrey Epstein while he was incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes an out-of-office message from a legal assistant, a complaint from Epstein's attorney about his treatment, and internal BOP communications about crafting a media response. This document consists of three Google Alert emails sent to Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff in August and November 2019, summarizing news coverage about the Federal Bureau of Prisons, primarily focused on the death of Jeffrey Epstein and the subsequent investigations and congressional hearings. The alerts highlight staffing shortages, security failures, and political responses. This document contains internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) email correspondence, including a forwarded Google Alert email. The primary content is a BOP staff email from Susan Allison forwarding a Google Alert about news coverage of the Bureau of Prisons following Jeffrey Epstein's death. The alert summarizes numerous news articles covering Epstein's suicide, the subsequent investigations, and broader criticisms of the BOP. This document contains internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) email correspondence from August 2019, including forwarded news alerts and internal discussions regarding the death of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). It highlights congressional scrutiny, internal investigations into staffing and procedural failures, and BOP officials coordinating responses. This document contains email correspondence among Bureau of Prisons (BOP) officials and a Department of Justice attorney in the immediate aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's death. It includes internal discussions about media coverage, a request for an update call with the Attorney General, and an email forwarding news articles about the suicide. It also contains a technical email about a corrupted psychological observation report and an internal notification about media inquiries regarding Epstein's earlier suicide attempt. This document consists of forwarded Google Alert emails sent to a Bureau of Prisons email address (babest@bop.gov) in August 2019. The alerts contain news articles and commentary about the death of Jeffrey Epstein in federal custody, the subsequent reassignment of prison staff, and widespread criticism of staffing shortages and security failures within the Federal Bureau of Prisons. This document is a collection of email correspondence from August 2019, primarily consisting of Google Alerts sent to Bureau of Prisons (BOP) officials regarding news coverage of Jeffrey Epstein's death and federal prison staffing issues. It includes internal BOP emails discussing the timeline of events leading to Epstein's death and verifying information for potential public release. This document contains email correspondence from the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) regarding the death of Jeffrey Epstein. It includes a draft press release announcing his death as an apparent suicide, internal emails about news alerts related to the Bureau of Prisons, and a later email distributing news clips about the indictment of correctional officers and congressional testimony concerning Epstein's death. This document contains email correspondence, primarily Google Alerts sent to a Bureau of Prisons employee regarding news coverage of Jeffrey Epstein's death by suicide. It also includes a brief internal email exchange about a corrupted document related to Epstein's psychological observation. The emails highlight the immediate media and institutional reaction to Epstein's death in custody. This document contains email correspondence between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff regarding a psychological observation report for Jeffrey Epstein and includes forwarded Google Alerts about public scrutiny of the BOP following Epstein's death. It shows internal BOP communication about Epstein's status and awareness of media coverage. This document contains email correspondence from August 2019, including Google Alerts sent to Bureau of Prisons staff about media coverage of Jeffrey Epstein's death and a separate email exchange regarding a court hearing. The emails show internal BOP communication about the intense scrutiny following Epstein's death and logistical coordination with the court. This document consists of email alerts from Google Alerts sent to Bureau of Prisons (BOP) employees, summarizing news coverage about the Bureau of Prisons in the immediate aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody. The alerts highlight investigations into the suicide, personnel changes, and broader criticisms of the BOP. This document contains email correspondence from August 2019, including Google Alerts about media coverage of Jeffrey Epstein's death in federal custody and internal Bureau of Prisons emails discussing the timeline of events leading to his suicide. The emails show BOP officials receiving media alerts and coordinating a public response with the Department of Justice. This document is an email chain from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) containing forwarded news articles about the fallout from Jeffrey Epstein's suicide. It includes an email from Hugh Hurwitz forwarding news clips about the indictment of the correctional officers on duty the night Epstein died, and a separate, earlier email chain from August 2019 about Hurwitz's reassignment following Epstein's death. The document reveals internal BOP communication regarding the public and political response to the incident. This document contains two email messages from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) system. The first is a Google Alert email from August 10, 2019, notifying a BOP official of news articles reporting Jeffrey Epstein's death by suicide in jail. The second is an internal BOP email from August 13, 2019, distributing a 'Noteworthy News Clips' compilation, which includes multiple articles about Epstein's death, the subsequent investigation, and related prison issues. This document is an email from Susan Allison to numerous Bureau of Prisons (BOP) officials, forwarding a 'Noteworthy News Clips' compilation dated October 31, 2019. The primary news clip is a New York Times article summarizing the dispute over Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy, with Dr. Michael Baden claiming evidence points to homicide and Dr. Barbara Sampson defending the suicide ruling. The email also contains metadata showing it was forwarded with an embedded Google Alert email from August 10, 2019, reporting on Epstein's death and the initial BOP statement. This document contains internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) email correspondence from July-August 2019, discussing media coverage and internal communications regarding Jeffrey Epstein's suicide attempt and subsequent death. It includes forwarded news alerts, internal inquiries about media leaks, and an email about processing a paralegal application for Epstein's case. This document contains email correspondence from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) regarding the death of Jeffrey Epstein on August 10, 2019. It includes official notification to the court, internal BOP communications about a potential leak, and a Google Alert digest about public and congressional scrutiny of the BOP following Epstein's death. This document contains internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) email correspondence and Google Alert summaries from July-August 2019 regarding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death. It includes an email about media inquiries into Epstein's suicide attempt and subsequent alerts about the fallout, including staff subpoenas, reassignments, and the official suicide ruling. This document is a collection of email alerts from Google Alerts sent to Bureau of Prisons (BOP) employees, primarily covering news articles about Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody, the subsequent removal of BOP leadership, and broader federal prison system issues. It reveals BOP staff were monitoring media coverage of the Epstein case closely. This document contains email correspondence from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) system, including Google Alerts and internal news digests. It focuses on the aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's death, the removal of BOP leadership, and related news coverage. The emails are sent to and from various BOP officials. This document contains email correspondence among Bureau of Prisons (BOP) officials on August 10, 2019, discussing the draft press release and details surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death by suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes internal questions and answers about the incident, the final press release, and subsequent Google Alerts about media coverage of Epstein's death and related investigations. This document appears to be a system log or audit trail showing archiving and tagging actions for electronic files, likely related to document management in the Epstein case. It contains timestamps of creation, export, and tagging events with system-generated identifiers.

Ayers includes Ormond in a mass distribution of news clips to BOP leadership.
Hurwitz is listed as a recipient of Ayers' news clips email; a news clip mentions his reassignment after Epstein's death.
News clips report two correctional officers were indicted for falsifying records and failing to monitor Epstein the night he died.
Brian Best, a BOP employee, was receiving automated news alerts about Epstein's death and the surrounding controversy, indicating institutional awareness.
Internal BOP colleagues communicating about resending a corrupted document related to Epstein's psychological observation.
As Attorney General, Barr publicly commented on the 'failure' and 'irregularities' surrounding Epstein's death in federal custody and vowed an investigation.
Charisma Edge copies Lamine N'Diaye on an initial email about Epstein's psychological observation.
Ormond is a BOP employee receiving information about inmate Epstein's psychological observation status.
As Attorney General, Barr is mentioned in news articles as reacting to Epstein's death and criticizing the BOP.
Scannell communicates on behalf of Warden Petrucci regarding his availability for a court hearing.
Scannell corresponds with court staff Murray regarding logistics for a hearing in the Epstein case.
Barr, as Attorney General, ordered the removal/reassignment of Warden N'Diaye following Epstein's death.
Dershowitz is identified as a lawyer for Epstein, commenting on his client's state of mind and death.
Barr oversees the Department of Justice, which includes the Bureau of Prisons led by Acting Director Hurwitz.
N'Diaye was the warden of the MCC where Epstein was held and died.
Kathleen Hawk Sawyer replaced Hugh Hurwitz as the director of the Bureau of Prisons following Epstein's death, as reported in a news article.
Attorney General William P. Barr announced the reassignment of acting director Hugh Hurwitz.
Hurwitz sent an email to Alison Leukefeld and other BOP staff forwarding news clips.
Geoffrey Berman, as U.S. Attorney, filed a motion to quash the charges against Epstein after his death.
Senator Ben Sasse pressed Bureau of Prisons Director Kathleen Hawk Sawyer about Epstein's death during testimony.
Mark Epstein is identified as Jeffrey Epstein's brother and only known living relative.
Co-authored a bipartisan letter to the BOP demanding answers about Epstein's death.
Nadler and Collins sent a letter to Hurwitz (Acting BOP Director) with questions about Epstein's death.
Susan Allison sent an internal news digest email to Bradley T Gross and other BOP colleagues.
Dr. Baden was hired by Epstein's brother to review the autopsy and publicly disputed the official suicide ruling, claiming evidence pointed to homicide.
As Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Sampson conducted the official autopsy and maintained the conclusion that Epstein died by suicide, directly countering Baden's claims.
Savella submitted Honigman's application to work as a paralegal on Epstein's case.
Johnson corresponds with Savella to process a paralegal application for Epstein's case.
Pistro forwards a news article to Hurwitz and other senior BOP officials 'For Your Situational Awareness' (FYSA).
Johnson, as a BOP supervisory attorney, sends official notification of Epstein's death to the court.
The warden of the MCC New York facility where Epstein died authors the official death notification.
Colleagues within the BOP communicating about a potential leak related to Epstein's death.
Plourde receives a reporter's inquiry about a potential leak and states it was sent to the FBI.
Barr, as Attorney General, oversaw the Department of Justice and Bureau of Prisons following Epstein's death, ordering reassignments and investigations.
News alert mentions Trump as one of Epstein's friends who came into the spotlight after Epstein's suicide.
Barr asked Sawyer to come out of retirement to resume leadership of the Bureau of Prisons following the Epstein incident.
Both are BOP employees who received similar Google Alert emails about federal prison news, including the Epstein case.
Linaweaver, a former MCC warden, commented on Sawyer's appointment as the new BOP director.
Barr, as Attorney General, removed Hurwitz from his position as acting director of the Bureau of Prisons.
Ayers sends an internal news digest email to Ormond and other BOP officials.
Both are BOP officials who receive similar Google Alerts and internal communications.
Plourde sends an email to N'Diaye regarding a draft press release on August 10, 2019.
Carroll emails N'Diaye with questions about Epstein's death for a press release, indicating a working relationship within the BOP.
Skipper-Scott forwards answers to press release questions to N'Diaye, showing internal BOP communication chain.
Savella, an attorney, emails Johnson, a BOP official, to request adding another attorney to Epstein's visitor list.

events.title: Epstein placed on Suicide Watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on suicide watch at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York.

events.title: Epstein removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was removed from suicide watch at MCC New York at 08:45.

events.title: Request for Epstein's Medical Records
events.description: A staff attorney at MCC New York emails a colleague requesting Epstein's medical and psych records in anticipation of a request from his defense attorneys.

events.title: Court Hearing on Dismissal of Indictment
events.description: Judge Berman schedules a hearing to address the proposed dismissal of the indictment against Jeffrey Epstein after his death, allowing counsel for the government, the deceased defendant, and victims to be heard.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Suicide Watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on suicide watch and received a medical evaluation at MCC-New York.

events.title: Epstein Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: After daily interaction, the MCC-New York Psychology Services Department determined Epstein no longer warranted suicide watch. He was returned to the SHU with a cellmate requirement.

events.title: Cellmate Removed; Epstein Without Cellmate
events.description: Epstein's cellmate was taken to court and released. Epstein, despite being on a PSYCH Alert requiring a cellmate, had no cellmate assigned for the night.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive and Pronounced Dead
events.description: At approximately 6:33 a.m., staff found Epstein unresponsive in his cell. CPR was administered, and he was pronounced dead at the hospital at 7:36 a.m.

events.title: News Article on Prison Guards Charged
events.description: A Daily Mail article reports that prison guards charged in connection with Jeffrey Epstein's death appeared in court.

events.title: Government Proposes Nolle Prosequi Order
events.description: The United States Attorney proposed an order to dismiss the indictment against Epstein.

events.title: Attorney Raises Issues on Epstein's Confinement Conditions
events.description: Attorney Mariel Colon emailed BOP staff regarding Epstein's lack of bathroom access, phone calls, and proper meals during legal meetings.

events.title: Jonathan Farley's Solicitation Letter to Epstein
events.description: Mathematician Jonathan Farley wrote to incarcerated Epstein proposing a $5 million donation to Morgan State University or Oxford in exchange for public support.

events.title: BOP Meeting Scheduled on Psychological Reconstruction
events.description: BOP staff were instructed to set up a meeting to discuss psychological reconstruction issues related to Epstein (posthumously).

events.title: Epstein Calls Jonathan Farley
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein called mathematician Jonathan Farley.

events.title: Skype Call with Epstein, Farley, and Student
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein, Jonathan Farley, and Farley's Ph.D. student Zeinab Bandpey had a Skype call.

events.title: Attorney requests improved conditions for Epstein
events.description: Attorney Mariel Colon emails Adam Johnson detailing complaints from Epstein about restricted bathroom access, lack of promised phone calls, and inability to eat proper meals while meeting with his legal team.

events.title: Epstein transferred to psych observation
events.description: The Suicide Watch Log notes Epstein was transferred to psych observation at 8:45 am, where the inmate companion was utilized until July 30.

events.title: Attorney coordination call scheduled
events.description: Attorney Michael Miller emails Adam Johnson to confirm a 2 pm call to continue discussions, following a delay in Epstein's morning schedule due to a shower, haircut, and medical assessment.

events.title: Attorney-Client Call Coordination
events.description: Email exchange regarding coordinating a 2 pm call between Epstein and his attorney, Michael Miller, noting a delay as Epstein was getting a shower, haircut, and medical assessment.

events.title: Judicial Inquiry to MCC Warden
events.description: Judge Richard M. Berman sends an inquiry to Warden N'Diaye regarding Jeffrey Epstein. The Warden provides a prompt response, which is forwarded by BOP staff.

events.title: Drafting of Epstein Reconstruction Report
events.description: BOP officials, including the National Suicide Prevention Coordinator and senior counsel, circulate and edit a draft document titled 'Epstein Reconstruction 76318-054', labeled as a working document not for distribution.

events.title: Florida Plea Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered a non-prosecution agreement and pleaded guilty to one count of Solicitation of Prostitution and one count of Procuring a Person Under the Age of 18 for Prostitution in Florida.

events.title: Federal Sex Trafficking Charges
events.description: Epstein was formally charged with Sex Trafficking Conspiracy and Sex Trafficking in the Southern District of New York, accused of sexually exploiting and abusing minor females over several years.

events.title: Arrest at Teterboro
events.description: Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey upon his return from Paris, France, and transported to the Metropolitan Correctional Complex (MCC) in New York.

events.title: Bail Denied
events.description: Judge Richard M. Berman denied Epstein's proposed bail package, determining he was a danger and a flight risk, and ordered him held on remand.

events.title: First Suicide Incident
events.description: Epstein was found in his cell with a piece of orange cloth around his neck, showing friction marks. It was undetermined if this was self-directed violence, an assault, or a feigned incident.

events.title: Documents Unsealed
events.description: Approximately 2,000 pages of documents were unsealed, including graphic allegations against Epstein and references to books on erotic servitude, part of a defamation lawsuit.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Epstein was found unresponsive in his SHU cell at approximately 6:33 a.m. Life-saving measures were attempted, but he was pronounced dead at a local hospital at 7:36 a.m.

events.title: Epstein Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was stepped down from suicide watch to psychological observation at MCC New York.

events.title: BOP Media Statement on Epstein's Location
events.description: BOP Public Affairs issued a final statement clarifying Epstein was housed at MCC New York, not a local hospital, and declining to share details on his medical status.

events.title: Epstein Found Dead
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his SHU cell at MCC New York.

events.title: Reconstruction of Epstein's Inmate Data
events.description: BOP staff were directed to reconstruct Epstein's 292 inmate record data for the week prior to his death, identified as a time-critical task.

events.title: Media Inquiry on Post-Epstein Conditions
events.description: NY Daily News inquired about morale, staffing, policy changes, and funding at MCC NY following Epstein's death and charges against staff Tova Noel and Michael Thomas.

events.title: Epstein placed in SHU pending classification
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was admitted to the Special Housing Unit at New York MCC at 19:20, authorized by S. Jean, pending classification.

events.title: Epstein admitted to SHU under new authorization
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was admitted to the Special Housing Unit at New York MCC at 15:26, authorized by Durant, pending classification.

events.title: Epstein admitted to SHU under M. Rice authorization
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was admitted to the Special Housing Unit at New York MCC at 12:21, authorized by M. Rice, pending classification.

events.title: BOP emails regarding reconstruction of Epstein's 292 data
events.description: BOP officials Michael Carvajal, Sonya Thompson, Ray Ormond, and Andy Black corresponded via email about reconstructing BP-292 data for inmate Epstein.

events.title: Epstein found dead
events.description: Inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his SHU cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC NY).

events.title: Epstein placed on suicide watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on suicide watch at MCC NY.

events.title: Epstein removed from suicide watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was removed from suicide watch at MCC NY.

events.title: BOP initiates data reconstruction
events.description: Andy Black sends an urgent email to Minchih Chen to reconstruct Epstein's 292 record for the week prior to his death.

events.title: SRO reports delivered
events.description: Minchih Chen delivers reconstructed SRO (Special Housing Unit Review) reports for Epstein covering periods in July and August 2019.

events.title: Epstein placed in Special Housing
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed in the Special Housing Unit at MCC New York, with the initial reason listed as 'PENDING CAPTAINS REVIEW'.

events.title: Epstein placed in SHU for self-mutilation
events.description: Epstein was placed in the Special Housing Unit with a new reason: 'PENDING DHO FOR CODE 228 SELF-MUTILATION', indicating an incident of self-harm.

events.title: Defense attorney complains about conditions
events.description: Attorney Mariel Colon emailed BOP Supervisory Staff Attorney Adam Johnson complaining that Epstein had no toilet paper, his CPAP machine was unplugged, and he had only made two monitored phone calls.

events.title: BOP discusses disposition of Epstein's funds
events.description: Internal BOP emails discuss the procedure for releasing Jeffrey Epstein's inmate trust account balance ($566.27) following his death, noting media discussion of his will.

events.title: BOP staff forwards news timeline
events.description: BOP staffer Charisma Edge forwarded a news article titled 'A timeline of what Jeffrey Epstein and his prison guards did in his final hours' to herself.

events.title: Email with Epstein Chronological Log
events.description: Laraine N'Diaye (Charisma Edge) emails Ray Ormond a chronological log detailing Epstein's transfer to psych observation on July 23-24, 2019.

events.title: Media Inquiry Email Forwarded
events.description: An email is forwarded regarding a media inquiry from the NY Daily News about conditions at MCC NY following Epstein's death and charges against officers Noel and Thomas.

events.title: Epstein Transferred to Psych Observation
events.description: According to the attached log, Epstein was transferred to psych observation on July 24, 2019, at 8:45 am, after an inmate companion assumed duties.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Suicide Watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on suicide watch at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York.

events.title: Suicide Watch Ended
events.description: Epstein's suicide watch was ended at 01:40.

events.title: Epstein Medically Cleared
events.description: Epstein was medically cleared at 08:45, following the end of his suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at MCC New York, an apparent suicide.

events.title: Judicial Inquiry and BOP Response
events.description: Judge Richard M. Berman sent an inquiry letter regarding Epstein. Warden Lamine N'Diaye responded, and Supervisory Staff Attorney Adam Johnson forwarded the response to the court.

events.title: Internal BOP Email on Media Scrutiny
events.description: Hugh Hurwitz emailed colleagues a HuffPost article titled 'Jeffrey Epstein Death Shines Light On Understaffed, Unaccountable Federal Prison System,' warning it may bring more scrutiny.

events.title: Internal BOP Email on Guard Charges
events.description: Lee Plourde forwarded a Daily Mail article to colleagues about prison guards being charged in connection with Epstein's death appearing in court.

events.title: Epstein stepped down from suicide watch
events.description: Chief Psychologist Elissa Miller informs HR that inmate Jeffrey Epstein was stepped down from suicide watch to psychological observation.

events.title: Judge Berman's inquiry to MCC
events.description: Judge Richard Berman sends a letter of inquiry to the MCC warden regarding Jeffrey Epstein, and receives a prompt response forwarded by Adam Johnson.

events.title: Scheduled hearing on dismissal of indictment
events.description: Judge Berman schedules a hearing to address the government's proposed dismissal of the indictment against Jeffrey Epstein following his death, inviting BOP staff and victims to be heard.

events.title: Request for Epstein's medical/psych records
events.description: BOP staff attorney Stephanie Scannell requests preparation of Epstein's medical and psychological records in anticipation of a request from his attorneys.

events.title: Internal sharing of Epstein autopsy article
events.description: Associate Warden Shirley Skipper-Scott forwards a Daily Mail article containing graphic photos from Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy to a colleague, commenting 'We will never be able to move forward with all the craziness!'

events.title: Email re: Epstein Medical/Mental Health Records
events.description: Email from Chae Un Chong to BOP staff regarding Epstein's medical/mental health records.

events.title: BOP Attempts to Obtain Autopsy Report
events.description: MCC New York Health Services Department begins trying to obtain Epstein's autopsy report, discharge summary, toxicology report, and death certificate.

events.title: Mortality Review Email
events.description: Terrance Thomas sends email stating continued inability to obtain Epstein's autopsy and other death-related reports from the Office of Chief Medical Examiner.

events.title: Reaction to Epstein Autopsy Article
events.description: Shawanda Y. Givens reacts to Daily Mail article showing graphic autopsy photos of Epstein and comments on items found in his cell.

events.title: Epstein Placed with Inmate Companion
events.description: Epstein was placed with an inmate companion from July 23, 2019, 7 am until July 24, 2019, 8:45 am.

events.title: Epstein Transferred to Psych Observation
events.description: Epstein was transferred to psych observation on July 24, 2019, at 8:45 am until July 30, 2019, at 8:15 am, with an inmate companion utilized.

events.title: Epstein placed on suicide watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on suicide watch at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York.

events.title: Suicide watch ended
events.description: Epstein's suicide watch period ended at 01:40.

events.title: Incident report for self-mutilation
events.description: Epstein was given an incident report for self-mutilation, according to an email from BOP staff.

events.title: Email update on injury investigation
events.description: BOP Supervisory Staff Attorney Adam Johnson emailed AUSA Maurene stating the investigation into Epstein's injuries was nearing completion and that claims against cellmate Tartaglione appeared unfounded.

events.title: Correspondence re: psychological observation reports
events.description: Associate Warden Charisma Edge emailed Ray Ormond to resend psychological observation reports for Epstein from July 8-10, 2019, after initial attachment issues.

events.title: Epstein removed from suicide watch
events.description: After daily interaction, MCC NY Psychology Services Department determined Epstein no longer warranted suicide watch. He was returned to SHU with a requirement to have a cellmate.

events.title: Cellmate removed, Epstein without cellmate
events.description: Epstein's cellmate was taken to court and released. Epstein was in a legal visit with his lawyers all day. He returned to his cell with no cellmate, despite being on a PSYCH Alert requiring one.

events.title: Epstein found unresponsive and pronounced dead
events.description: At approximately 6:33 a.m., staff found Epstein unresponsive in his cell. CPR was administered. He was transported to a hospital and pronounced dead at 7:36 a.m.

events.title: Media inquiries about Epstein's status
events.description: BOP Public Affairs, DOJ, and USMS coordinate on drafting a final media response to inquiries about Epstein, stating he is housed at MCC NY and not in a local hospital.

events.title: Media inquiry about MCC NY conditions post-Epstein
events.description: NY Daily News inquires about morale, hiring, policy changes, and facility improvements at MCC NY following Epstein's suicide and charges against officers Noel and Thomas.

events.title: Official Notification of Epstein's Death
events.description: Adam Johnson, Supervisory Staff Attorney at MCC, sends official notification of Jeffrey Epstein's passing to the US Marshals Service, citing an ongoing investigation.

events.title: BuzzFeed Reporter Inquiry on Potential Leak
events.description: Reporter Jane Lytvynenko contacts the BOP about suspected leaks from a paramedic regarding Epstein's death, citing 4chan posts that appeared 45 minutes before ABC News reported it.

events.title: NY Daily News Media Inquiry on MCC Conditions
events.description: Reporter Stephen Brown sends a detailed list of questions to the BOP about plummeting morale, staffing, funding, and policy changes at MCC following Epstein's suicide and charges against officers Noel and Thomas.

events.title: Google Alert on BOP Scrutiny Post-Epstein
events.description: A Google Alert email summarizes numerous news articles highlighting increased scrutiny of the Federal Bureau of Prisons following Jeffrey Epstein's death, covering congressional inquiries, staffing issues, and Barr's comments.

events.title: Official Death Notification to Court
events.description: Warden Lamine N'Diaye sent a formal letter via email to Chief Judge Colleen McMahon and Judge Richard M. Berman notifying them of Jeffrey Epstein's death.

events.title: Media Inquiry on MCC Conditions
events.description: NY Daily News reporter Stephen Brown made an inquiry about morale, staffing, and policy changes at MCC New York following Epstein's suicide and the charges against officers Tova Noel and Michael Thomas.

events.title: BOP issues media statement on Epstein's location
events.description: Justin B. Long distributes the final DOJ-approved statement clarifying Epstein is housed at MCC NY and not in a hospital, and that medical/confidentiality details will not be shared.

events.title: Night of Epstein's death
events.description: Referenced in urgent DOJ questions about correctional officer absenteeism on the overnight shift between Friday 8/09 and Saturday 8/10 at MCC NY.

events.title: DOJ demands urgent staffing review
events.description: DOJ JMD Budget staff, via Amit Kumar, sends an immediate-turnaround request to BOP with 11 detailed questions about MCC NY staffing, vacancies, and operations related to Epstein's death.

events.title: Leak of Epstein's autopsy photos
events.description: Associate Warden Shirley Skipper-Scott emails a colleague about graphic autopsy photos of Epstein being published online, questioning whether the examiner had approval to release them.

events.title: Reuters/Breitbart Report on Guard Checks
events.description: A news report claims prison guards skipped mandatory checks before Jeffrey Epstein's death.

events.title: Epstein Given Incident Report for Self-Mutilation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was given an incident report for self-mutilation while in custody at MCC.

events.title: Google Alert on Epstein Suicide Aftermath
events.description: A Google Alert email aggregates multiple news stories about Epstein's suicide, the investigations launched, and expert criticism of BOP procedures.

events.title: NY Daily News Media Inquiry
events.description: The NY Daily News inquires about morale, staffing, and policy changes at MCC NY following the charges against officers Noel and Thomas post-Epstein's suicide.

events.title: Internal Update on Epstein Injury Investigation
events.description: Adam Johnson informs AUSA Maurene that the investigation into Epstein's injuries is nearing completion, and claims against inmate Tartaglione appear unfounded.

events.title: Inquiry about Epstein Injury Investigation
events.description: AUSA Maurene emails BOP attorneys asking if the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's injuries is still ongoing ahead of a court conference.

events.title: Update on Epstein Injury Investigation
events.description: Adam Johnson responds that the investigation is nearing completion, Epstein was given an incident report for self-mutilation, and claims against Tartaglione appear unfounded.

events.title: Court Hearing Before Judge Berman
events.description: Judge Berman invites the MCC Warden and Stephanie Scannell to a hearing; the Warden declines but Scannell attends.

events.title: Paralegal Application Submission for Epstein
events.description: Attorney Jonathan Savella submits an application for paralegal Samanta Honigman to work on Jeffrey Epstein's case.

events.title: Request to Add Attorney to Visitor List
events.description: Attorney Jonathan Savella emails BOP official Adam Johnson to request that attorney Erika Ann Kellerhals be added to Jeffrey Epstein's approved visitor list.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Death in Custody
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by apparent suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in Manhattan.

events.title: Autopsy Reveals Broken Neck Bones
events.description: An autopsy found Epstein sustained multiple breaks in his neck bones, deepening questions around his death.

events.title: Google Alert on Federal Prisoners Sent
events.description: A Google Alert email summarizing news about federal prisoners, prominently featuring Epstein's death, was sent to BOP official Brian Best.

events.title: BOP Drafts Media Response on MCC Conditions
events.description: BOP Public Information Officer Justin Long drafts a Q&A for media inquiries about morale, staffing, and policy changes at MCC New York following Epstein's death and staff charges.

events.title: Meeting regarding Epstein's conditions
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein met with Dr. Miller, Lieutenant Rice, and Mr. Plourde to discuss his conditions of confinement, including bathroom access and phone calls.

events.title: Attorney complaint about Epstein's conditions
events.description: Attorney Mariel Colon emailed MCC staff detailing complaints about Epstein's treatment, including denied bathroom access, lack of phone calls, and inadequate meals.

events.title: BOP media statement coordination
events.description: Internal BOP emails coordinate the dissemination of a final, DOJ-approved media statement in response to numerous inquiries about Jeffrey Epstein's status and conditions.

events.title: Google Alert on Epstein's death
events.description: A Google Alert email sent to BOP staff summarizes numerous news reports about Jeffrey Epstein's death by suicide in his MCC jail cell and the ensuing investigations.

events.title: Media inquiry on post-Epstein conditions
events.description: An email regarding a media inquiry about conditions at MCC New York in the period following Jeffrey Epstein's death.

events.title: Revelation of Guard Failures
events.description: News reports revealed that guards had not checked on Epstein for several hours before his death, violating protocol, and that he had been left alone after his cellmate was transferred.

events.title: Barr Orders Investigation
events.description: Attorney General William Barr announced that Inspector General Michael Horowitz would investigate the circumstances surrounding Epstein's death.

events.title: Senate Judiciary Committee Hearing
events.description: The Senate Judiciary Committee held an oversight hearing on the Federal Bureau of Prisons, where Director Kathleen Hawk Sawyer was questioned about Epstein's death, staffing shortages, and the possibility of a 'criminal enterprise'.

events.title: House Oversight Committee Investigation Launched
events.description: The House Oversight Committee launched an investigation into the Trump administration's decision to resume federal executions, sending letters to Attorney General Barr and BOP Acting Director Hurwitz.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Death in BOP Custody
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by apparent suicide while in federal custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), prompting multiple investigations.

events.title: BOP Warden Reassigned
events.description: Attorney General William Barr ordered the removal/reassignment of the warden at the federal jail where Epstein died.

events.title: BOP Internal News Clips Email
events.description: BOP employee Susan Allison sent an internal email titled 'Noteworthy News Clips 8-12-2019' to a list of BOP colleagues, forwarding media coverage about the BOP post-Epstein.

events.title: DOJ/BOP Coordination Call Requested
events.description: DOJ official Timothy Shea emailed BOP Acting Director Hugh Hurwitz and Ray Ormond requesting a quick update call on the Epstein death before traveling with the Attorney General.

events.title: Warden Removed, Guards Placed on Leave
events.description: Attorney General William Barr ordered the removal of the warden at the MCC and placed two guards on leave following the discovery of 'serious irregularities' related to Epstein's death.

events.title: Epstein Autopsy Results Released
events.description: The New York City Medical Examiner's office concluded Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide. Epstein's lawyers stated they were 'not satisfied' with the results.

events.title: Prince Andrew Issues Statement
events.description: Britain's Prince Andrew released a statement saying he was 'appalled' by Epstein's alleged crimes and denying any involvement or condoning of such behavior.

events.title: Reuters Report on Guard Checks
events.description: Reuters publishes a report alleging prison guards skipped mandatory checks before Jeffrey Epstein's death.

events.title: DOJ/BOP Update Call Requested
events.description: DOJ attorney Timothy Shea requests a quick update call with BOP officials Hugh Hurwitz and Ray Ormond regarding the Epstein news, before a trip with the Attorney General.

events.title: Epstein's Psychological Observation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on a psych observation from July 8, 6 pm until July 10 at 9 am, utilizing an 'I/M companion'.

events.title: Media Inquiries on Suicide Attempt
events.description: BOP official Glenda Anderson-Layne is informed that the US Marshals Service and the Daily News are making inquiries about Jeffrey Epstein's earlier suicide attempt.

events.title: Compilation of Epstein News Clips
events.description: BOP official Susan Allison distributes a compilation of 'Noteworthy News Clips' to senior BOP staff, containing multiple articles about Epstein's death, investigations, and related political reactions.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein found dead in cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center around 6:30 a.m. in an apparent suicide.

events.title: Warden reassigned, guards suspended
events.description: Following Epstein's death, Attorney General Barr directed the reassignment of Warden Lamine N'Diaye and the suspension of two staff members assigned to Epstein's unit.

events.title: This Week transcript on ABC
events.description: Senator Cory Booker discussed Epstein's death, the outrage from accusers, and questions about how it could happen in a maximum security federal prison.

events.title: Cellmate Removed and Not Replaced
events.description: Epstein's cellmate was taken out for a court appearance and was eventually released from custody, not returning to the institution. Epstein was left without a cellmate despite being on a PSYCH Alert requiring one.

events.title: Failure to Perform Required Checks
events.description: After midnight on August 10th, it appears that not all of the required 30-minute checks on Epstein's cell were actually performed.

events.title: Epstein's Death Ruled Suicide
events.description: The medical examiner's office ruled Jeffrey Epstein's prison death a suicide by hanging.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein at MCC New York
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center at approximately 6:30 a.m. Life-saving measures were initiated, and he was transported to a hospital where he was pronounced dead. The incident was investigated as an apparent suicide.

events.title: BOP Drafts Press Release on Epstein Death
events.description: Michael Carroll emails Ray Ormond a draft press release announcing Epstein's death as an apparent suicide, indicating internal BOP communication about the incident.

events.title: Indictment of Correctional Officers
events.description: Two correctional officers on duty the night Epstein died were indicted on charges including falsifying government records. Allegations state they were sleeping and browsing the internet instead of monitoring him.

events.title: BOP Director Testifies Before Senate
events.description: Bureau of Prisons Director Kathleen Hawk Sawyer testified before a Senate panel, stating she had 'no evidence' Epstein's death was not a suicide, while Senator Ben Sasse pressed her on the failure.

events.title: Epstein Arrives at MCC New York
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein arrived at the Metropolitan Correctional Center under pretrial status after being indicted for Sex Trafficking of Minors and Sex Trafficking Conspiracy.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein Found Dead
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his jail cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in an apparent suicide. The Bureau of Prisons announced his death.

events.title: Barr Comments on Jail Irregularities
events.description: Attorney General William Barr publicly decried a 'failure' by federal detention officials to secure Epstein and cited 'serious irregularities' at the MCC facility.

events.title: Internal BOP Email on Corrupted Document
events.description: Charisma Edge emails Ray Ormond to resend emails and a corrupted attachment related to Epstein's psychological observation from July.

events.title: End of Psychological Observation
events.description: A psychological observation for Jeffrey Epstein was scheduled from 6 pm on July 8, 2019, until 9 am on July 10, 2019.

events.title: Email Correspondence on Epstein Report
events.description: Charisma Edge and Ray Ormond exchange emails regarding a psychological observation report for Jeffrey Epstein, with issues opening attachments.

events.title: Google Alerts on BOP Scrutiny
events.description: Ray Ormond and Lamine N'Diaye receive Google Alerts with news articles about increased scrutiny of the Bureau of Prisons following Jeffrey Epstein's death.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Referenced in news articles within the Google Alerts as the event that triggered investigations and scrutiny of the Federal Bureau of Prisons.

events.title: Warden Reassigned
events.description: Attorney General William Barr directed the Bureau of Prisons to temporarily reassign the warden of MCC New York following Epstein's death.

events.title: Court Hearing Scheduling
events.description: Email exchange regarding the scheduling of a court hearing in USA v. Jeffrey Epstein, with the warden declining an invitation due to a conflict.

events.title: Epstein's Death Ruled Suicide
events.description: The New York City medical examiner officially ruled Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody a suicide by hanging.

events.title: BOP Personnel Actions After Epstein Death
events.description: Following Epstein's death, two guards were suspended and placed on administrative leave, and Warden Lamine N'Diaye was reassigned.

events.title: Multiple Investigations Launched
events.description: The FBI, the Justice Department's inspector general, and the Bureau of Prisons launched investigations into the circumstances surrounding Epstein's death.

events.title: Google Alert Email Sent
events.description: A Google Alert summarizing news about the 'bureau of prisons' was sent to BOP employee Ray Ormond.

events.title: Epstein's cellmate released, legal visit
events.description: Epstein's cellmate was taken to court and released, not returning to MCC. Epstein was in a legal visit with his lawyers until 6:45 p.m. He returned to a cell with no cellmate, violating the PSYCH Alert requirement.

events.title: Media coverage and internal BOP/DOJ coordination
events.description: Widespread media coverage of Epstein's death, prison security failures, and staffing shortages. Internal emails show BOP officials Hurwitz and Ormond receiving alerts and DOJ official Shea seeking verification of a timeline for public release.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan.

events.title: Reassignment of BOP Acting Director
events.description: Attorney General William P. Barr announced the reassignment of acting Bureau of Prisons director Hugh Hurwitz, a direct fallout from Epstein's death.

events.title: Senate Testimony on Epstein Death
events.description: Bureau of Prisons Director Kathleen Hawk Sawyer testified before a Senate panel, stating she had 'no evidence' Epstein's death was not a suicide, while also revealing the FBI was investigating a potential 'criminal enterprise' role.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein Found Dead in Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead by apparent suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan.

events.title: Barr Announces Investigation into Epstein Death
events.description: Attorney General William Barr announced an investigation into 'serious irregularities' at the MCC following Epstein's death, expressing anger at the facility's failure.

events.title: House Judiciary Committee Demands Answers
events.description: House Judiciary Committee leaders Jerrold Nadler and Doug Collins sent a letter to BOP Acting Director Hugh Hurwitz demanding answers about Epstein's death.

events.title: Epstein Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was removed from suicide watch at the request of his attorneys and after psychological evaluations, and placed on 'special observation status'.

events.title: Internal BOP News Digest Circulated
events.description: BOP employee Susan Allison circulated an internal 'Noteworthy News Clips' email to numerous colleagues, containing articles about Epstein's death and related issues.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein Found Dead in Jail Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan; the Bureau of Prisons initially called it an 'apparent suicide'.

events.title: Autopsy Dispute Publicized
events.description: Dr. Michael Baden publicly claimed evidence from Epstein's autopsy pointed to homicide, while Dr. Barbara Sampson defended the official suicide ruling.

events.title: BOP News Clips Distributed
events.description: Susan Allison distributed an email titled 'Noteworthy News Clips 10-31-2019' to a long list of BOP officials, highlighting news about Epstein's death and autopsy dispute.

events.title: Paralegal Application Processed
events.description: Adam Johnson routes an application for paralegal Samanta Honigman to work on Jeffrey Epstein's case, as submitted by attorney Jonathan Savella.

events.title: Inquiries on Epstein Suicide Attempt
events.description: BOP employee Glenda Anderson-Layne reports that the US Marshals Service and the Daily News are making inquiries about Jeffrey Epstein's recent suicide attempt.

events.title: Media Report on Skipped Checks
events.description: Reuters/Breitbart reports that prison guards skipped mandatory checks before Jeffrey Epstein's death, prompting an angry internal email from BOP Acting Director Hugh Hurwitz.

events.title: Google Alert on BOP Scrutiny
events.description: A Google Alert email is sent summarizing widespread news coverage criticizing the Bureau of Prisons following Jeffrey Epstein's death.

events.title: News Article Forwarded on MCC
events.description: BOP employee Kevin Pistro forwards a news article about an inmate release at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) to senior BOP officials.

events.title: Daily Digest on Epstein Death
events.description: A Google Alert daily digest is sent to Hugh Hurwitz, aggregating numerous news articles about the investigation into Epstein's death and the BOP's failures.

events.title: Official BOP Notification to Court
events.description: Warden N'Diaye sends an official letter via email to Judges McMahon and Berman notifying them of Epstein's death.

events.title: BuzzFeed Inquiry re: Potential Leak
events.description: Reporter Jane Lytvynenko contacts the BOP suspecting a paramedic leaked details of Epstein's death on 4chan 45 minutes before mainstream media reported it.

events.title: Google Alert on BOP Scrutiny
events.description: A Google Alert digest is sent to Hugh Hurwitz summarizing news articles about increased scrutiny of the BOP following Epstein's death, including congressional demands for answers.

events.title: Inquiry into Epstein Suicide Attempt
events.description: BOP internal email notes that the US Marshals Service and the Daily News were making inquiries about inmate Jeffrey Epstein's suicide attempt.

events.title: Epstein's Death and Aftermath
events.description: News alerts report Jeffrey Epstein's death by suicide, the reassignment of the BOP director and jail warden, subpoenas for prison guards, and the medical examiner's ruling of suicide by hanging.

events.title: Google Alert on BOP and Epstein
events.description: Google Alert sent to BOP employee Brian Best summarizing news about Epstein's removal from suicide watch, staff subpoenas, and reassignments.

events.title: Google Alert on BOP Systemic Issues
events.description: Google Alert sent to BOP employee Ray Ormond with news about a former BOP official blaming systemic issues for troubles at the facility that held Epstein, and the medical examiner ruling his death a suicide.

events.title: BOP Leadership Removed
events.description: Attorney General William Barr removed the acting director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons and installed new leadership, including bringing back former director Kathleen Hawk Sawyer.

events.title: Google Alert to BOP Staff
events.description: Google Alert email with news about 'federal prisoners', including Epstein's death, was sent to BOP employee Brian Best.

events.title: Medical Examiner Confirms Suicide
events.description: The medical examiner confirmed Jeffrey Epstein's cause of death was suicide by hanging.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan and later pronounced dead, an apparent suicide.

events.title: BOP Leadership Removal
events.description: Attorney General William Barr removed the acting head of the Bureau of Prisons, Hugh Hurwitz, following Epstein's suicide.

events.title: Prison Guards Indicted
events.description: Two correctional officers who guarded Jeffrey Epstein on the night he died were indicted on federal charges for allegedly ignoring mandatory checks and fabricating records.

events.title: Federal Executions Halted
events.description: A federal judge halted all four scheduled federal executions, finding Attorney General Barr's lethal injection protocol appeared at odds with federal law.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein found unresponsive and dies
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC New York at approximately 6:30 a.m. Life-saving measures were initiated, EMS transported him to a local hospital, where he was pronounced dead at approximately 7:36 a.m.

events.title: Epstein arrives at MCC New York
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein first arrived at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York on July 6, 2019, under pretrial status.

events.title: Request to add attorney to Epstein's visitor list
events.description: Attorney Jonathan Savella emails BOP official Adam Johnson to request adding attorney Erika Ann Kellerhals to Jeffrey Epstein's visiting list.

events.title: Medical examiner rules Epstein death a suicide
events.description: Google Alert email references news that the NYC medical examiner ruled Epstein's death a suicide by hanging, though his lawyers were not satisfied.

events.title: News coverage and investigations following Epstein's death
events.description: Google Alert email summarizes news articles about Epstein's death, including reports of jail rule violations, lack of monitoring, and ongoing federal investigations.

events.title: Archive Job Created
events.description: An archiving job was created by Archive Agent_I-Daly, generated by Netrre8 Inc.

events.title: Multiple File Exports
events.description: Multiple export actions occurred from the system on this date.

events.title: Additional File Exports
events.description: Further export actions were performed from the system.

events.description: Files were tagged with identifiers BOP01703.MXRADMI.AIXRDOMI and BOP01703.MXRADMI.AIXRIHMI and marked as 'Responsive' and 'Flagged'.

Detailed, handwritten suicide watch observation logs were maintained, requiring observations every 15 minutes.
Following Epstein's death, his defense attorneys were expected to request his medical and mental health records.

Judge Richard Berman scheduled a hearing for August 27, 2019, to address the dismissal of the indictment against Jeffrey Epstein, citing a public informational interest.

Internal BOP emails detail a specific timeline: Epstein was on suicide watch from July 23-29, 2019, then housed with a cellmate until August 9, when the cellmate was released and not replaced, contrary to a PSYCH Alert.
BOP official Hugh Hurwitz expressed caution about releasing the timeline of Epstein's death, noting it was subject to an ongoing OIG/FBI investigation.
A news article from November 2019 regarding prison guards being charged in Epstein's death was circulated among BOP staff.

Epstein's attorney, Mariel Colon, complained to BOP staff about restrictive conditions, including Epstein being denied bathroom breaks during legal meetings unless a lieutenant was present.
